hints.content: Start by understanding what a 'chunk' means in this context. A chunk is a contiguous subarray of the original array that can be sorted independently. Think about how sorting these chunks would affect the overall order of the array.

Consider the properties of the input array. Since it is a permutation of integers from 0 to n-1, each integer appears exactly once. This means that any integer's position in the array can give you insight into how to form chunks.
To determine if a chunk can be sorted independently, think about the maximum value in the chunk. The maximum value should match the index of the last element in that chunk when the array is sorted.
As you iterate through the array, keep track of the maximum value you've seen so far. This will help you determine when you can safely end a chunk.
Use a variable to track the current maximum value as you traverse the array. Whenever the current index matches this maximum value, you have identified a valid chunk.
Remember that you need to return the count of chunks. Each time you find a valid chunk, increment your chunk counter.
Think about edge cases, such as when the array is already sorted or when it is in reverse order. How would your logic handle these scenarios?
Consider what happens if the array has only one element. How many chunks can you form in that case? This will help you understand the lower bounds of your solution.
As you implement your solution, ensure that you are correctly handling the end of the array. You might need to check if the last chunk is valid after the loop finishes.
To summarize your approach: Iterate through the array, track the maximum value, and count chunks whenever the current index matches the maximum value. This should lead you to the final solution.

questionNotes: Input is a permutation of integers from 0 to n-1.
Array length n is between 1 and 10.
Return the largest number of chunks that can be sorted independently.
